intro: Cerastium papuanum subsp. phaenops, commonly known as the Papuan mouse-ear, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the high altitudes of New Guinea. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending stems covered with dense, glandular hairs. The plant produces small, white or pink flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in the spring and early summer. Its leaves are ovate to elliptic, with a hairy surface and a distinctive basal rosette formation. This subspecies is adapted to rocky and alpine environments, showcasing a range of morphological traits suited to its harsh habitat.
